#Text=Modeling habitat suitability of wild rice (Zizania�spp) to inform restoration efforts in Michigan, USA.

#Text=Abha Panda,�Shane Lishawa,�Jason Tallant,�Danielle Fegan\rFirst published: 14 June 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14205\rAuthor contributions: AP, SL conceived and designed research project; AP, SL, JT built the habitat model and analyzed the data; JT, DF helped acquire data and interpret findings; AP, SL, JT, DF wrote/edited the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Stuart Allison\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Wild rice (Zizania aquatica�and�Zizania palustris) has been an integral component of Michigan wetlands for thousands of years, but is disappearing today due to habitat loss.
#Text=Identifying suitable habitats and associated environmental conditions for wild rice viability is a critical step toward guiding ongoing restoration efforts statewide.

#Text=To this end, we used maximum entropy (Maxent), a presence_only species distribution model, to characterize habitat preferences of wild rice in Michigan and identify suitable habitats for restoration.
#Text=Extant wild rice occurrences were mapped alongside 11 environmental variables using Maxent to determine probabilities of occurrence throughout the state.
#Text=The Maxent model (AUC>0.9) predicted the highest probabilities of wild rice occurrence in the western and southwestern regions of the state.

#Text=Climatic variables, biotic interactions, and anthropogenic disturbances were all found to influence wild rice occurrence, with land cover, lower May precipitation, and minimum winter temperatures having the highest contributions to model predictions.

#Text=The results of this study suggest that statewide restoration of wild rice in Michigan may be possible, although localized differences in environmental conditions should be accounted for when selecting restoration sites.

#Text=With further refinement and the inclusion of more key environmental predictors of wild rice viability, habitat suitability models such as the one created in this study may be powerful and effective tools in guiding wild rice restoration efforts nationally.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Species distribution models can inform rare species detection and guide the selection of suitable sites for restoration across large landscapes.\r* Lower precipitation, colder temperatures, and land cover can influence wild rice occurrence and may be critical considerations for selecting restoration sites.\r* Although there is broad potential for using models to prioritize habitat for restoration, our findings highlight the need for more detailed statewide environmental datasets, particularly those related to aquatic plants and habitats, that may improve model predictions and restoration outcomes.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Wild rice (Zizania aquatica�and�Zizania palustris) is a native grass that has been an integral part of aquatic Laurentian Great Lakes ecosystems for thousands of years, but faces extensive population decline today due to habitat loss (Porter�2019).
#Text=Before European settlement, dense beds of wild rice were found in lakes and rivers across the region where they were commonly harvested by Anishinaabek tribes for sustenance (Barton�2018).
#Text=Since the 1800s, however, dredging, urban development and other anthropogenic disturbances have greatly degraded the wetland habitats where wild rice occurs.
#Text=In states such as Michigan (USA), only an estimated 1% of historic wild rice beds remain today (Barton�2018).
#Text=While the steady decline of wild rice populations has diminished its presence in Great Lakes wetlands, successful restoration can confer significant ecological and cultural benefits.

#Text=Many Anishinaabek communities across the region, who typically refer to the plant as�Manoomin, continue to steward wild rice stands for food and cultural practices, which has been critical to its persistence.

#Text=Wild rice harvests can provide significant monetary benefits for communities as well and have been estimated to contribute up to $19 million of profit annually for harvesters in Minnesota (Fletcher et al�2018).
#Text=In addition, a wide range of wetland species utilize wild rice beds throughout their life cycle.

#Text=Waterfowl, muskrats, waterbirds, and invertebrates have been noted to consume nutrient_rich seeds and shoots during the early life stages of wild rice and use mature stalks for shelter (Rogosin�1954; Huseby et al�2001; Lowdon�2006).

#Text=For our study, we focused on wild rice populations in Michigan that have seen some of the most extensive declines in the region and are the focus of many wetland restoration initiatives (Barton�2018).
#Text=Two species of wild rice�Z. palustris�and�Z. aquatica�currently co_occur in Michigan and are focal species for restoration.

#Text=Tribal and governmental agencies have been involved in efforts to restore these species to their historic ranges since the nineteenth century, yet few restoration projects have been successful and replicable at a larger scale statewide (Barton�2018).
#Text=A lack of knowledge about suitable contemporary habitats for restoration, in particular, may have posed a barrier to restoration success in the past (Bonnette�1999; Barton�2018; Porter�2019).
#Text=Wild rice restoration projects in Michigan have relied largely on community knowledge, historical data, and localized environmental conditions to identify suitable habitats (Barton�2018).
#Text=Yet, these may not account for the rate and extent to which anthropogenic disturbance has degraded historic wetlands or is replicable at larger scales.

#Text=Surveys of plant reintroductions have found that the inability to identify suitable habitats, particularly in fragmented and degraded habitats, is a primary barrier to the successful reintroduction of threatened species (Bottin et al�2007; Godefroid et al�2011).
#Text=A better understanding of optimal environmental conditions for wild rice viability in Michigan may consequently be critical to its restoration.
#Text=A wide range of environmental variables may play a role in wild rice viability throughout its life cycle.
#Text=Water depth, for instance, has been identified as particularly influential as seeds require saturated wetland soils to germinate (Vennum�1988; Kjerland�2015).

#Text=Sufficiently cold temperatures also need to be met during overwintering to break seed dormancy, and in years when proper freezing conditions are not reached, seeds remain dormant in wetland sediments or may not germinate at all (Myrbo et al�2017; Rickman et al�2017).

#Text=After germination, water level changes due to sudden precipitation, damming, or recreational activity can cause uprooting, particularly during the floating leaf stage when plants begin sending shoots to the water surface (Whigham & Simpson�1977; Rickman et al�2017).

#Text=Water chemistry can also play a large role during these critical stages, with both natural and anthropogenic inputs of nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfate having been noted as key deterrents to wild rice viability (Pillsbury & McGuire�2009; Sims et al�2012; Fort et al�2014).

#Text=In addition, biotic interactions have been found to be influential as plant communities may outcompete wild rice, particularly when large macrophytes are present (Engel & Nichols�1994; Yost & Blinnikov�2011), and herbivory by birds and muskrats have been noted to destroy wild rice beds (Takos�1947; Rogosin�1954).

#Text=Because wild rice viability is influenced by such a wide range of biotic and abiotic factors, understanding how these factors relate to environmental conditions in Michigan is crucial in guiding restoration efforts.

#Text=The distribution of wild rice in relation to environmental parameters has been previously analyzed to some extent in states such as Minnesota and Wisconsin where it has been found to occur along climatic and geologic gradients favoring ecoregions with higher latitudes, longer and colder winters, and lower alkalinity soils (Drewes & Silbernagel�2012; Myrbo et al�2017).
#Text=Yet, little is known about the range of suitable habitats in Michigan.
#Text=We used species distribution modeling to better understand wild rice habitat preferences in Michigan and identify potential sites for restoration.
#Text=Species distribution models (SDMs) are an effective and commonly used tool for predicting suitable habitat for a given species outside of their current range.

#Text=By statistically relating species distributions to environmental conditions, SDMs can make predictions about species habitat preferences and determine which environmental variables are key drivers of species occurrence (Guisan & Zimmermann�2000; Elith & Leathwick�2009).

#Text=SDMs have consequently been used in a wide range of ecological applications, including the restoration of threatened and rare plant species (Gaston & Garcia_Vinas�2013; Questad et al�2014; Zellmer et al�2019).
#Text=Maximum entropy (Maxent) is a species distribution modeling method that has been noted for its usefulness in making predictions for species for which there is limited information.
#Text=Maxent functions as a machine learning algorithm that uses presence_only data to make predictions about species occurrence (Phillips et al�2006; Elith & Leathwick�2009).

#Text=Because the Maxent model does not require complete knowledge of species distribution (both presence and absence), it is especially effective in predicting habitat ranges for species like wild rice, which may have limited datasets based on observation data only (Elith & Leathwick�2009; Merow et al�2013).

#Text=In this study, we used Maxent to model wild rice habitat suitability across the state of Michigan to (1) identify key environmental variables that might influence wild rice occurrence and (2) predict suitable sites for wild rice restoration throughout the state.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Wild Rice Occurrence Data.
#Text=We used 170 statewide occurrences of wild rice to build our habitat suitability model.

#Text=Occurrence data for wild rice in Michigan remains limited in scale as few comprehensive statewide surveys of existing wild rice sites have been conducted, and site_specific occurrence information is kept private by many Tribes and Indigenous wild rice caretakers.

#Text=As such, the wild rice occurrence data used in this study was compiled from a wide variety of primary and secondary academic, tribal, and governmental sources and was made available for this study on the condition that we do not release occurrence locations publicly (Barton, unpublished).
#Text=It should be noted that no distinction between�Zizania palustris�and�Zizania aquatica�was made in the dataset, and therefore, this study looks at the occurrence of both species simultaneously.
#Text=Overall, occurrences spanned the geographic extent of Michigan, including both coastal and inland locations, and ranged in timescale from the 1800s until 2017.
#Text=Because wild rice beds experience significant interannual variation, seeds can remain viable for up to several decades without germinating (Rickman et al�2017; Porter�2019).

#Text=Consequently, we considered sites where wild rice occurrence was directly observed in the past two decades as extant, and removed historical sites in which wild rice occurrence was only observed before the 2000s.
#Text=Similarly, many wild rice sites have been seeded throughout the decades for restoration and harvesting purposes.
#Text=We removed seeded sites that are no longer viable from the dataset, regardless of when seeding occurred.
#Text=Environmental Variables\rSDMs require careful selection of environmental parameters that are grounded in a species' ecology (Guisan & Zimmermann�2000; Phillips et al�2006; Merow et al�2013).
#Text=We sought to use the knowledge of experts paired with widely_available scientific information to identify important environmental parameters for wild rice.
#Text=We identified members of the Michigan Wild Rice Initiative (MWRI) as local experts.
#Text=The MWRI is a collaboration between the State of Michigan and the 12 federally recognized tribes in Michigan that seek to conserve and restore wild rice within the state.

#Text=The MWRI members provided unique insight based on Anishinaabe ecological knowledge and experience to supplement the available scientific literature which is limited in information about wild rice in Michigan.

#Text=We initially identified 32 variables of interest with publicly available statewide data, including bioclimatic variables, land cover, plant communities, wetland occurrence, plant cold_hardiness zones, dam presence, and muskrat presence.
#Text=A full list of all considered variables can be found in Table�S1.
#Text=Highly correlated variables can result in less interpretable Maxent models with less predictive power (Phillips�2017; Merow et al�2013).

#Text=As such, correlations between variables were examined using Spearman's correlation tests in the Hmisc package (Harrell & Dupont�2020), and in cases where two or more variables were highly correlated (r>0.8), only one was included in the model.

#Text=We selected correlated variables based on Maxent's jackknife test of variable contribution that examines the contribution of each variable individually to model predictions based on changes in area under the receiving operator curve (AUC) (Phillips et al�2006).

#Text=Correlated variables that were ecologically relevant and contributed least to the predictive power of the model were removed in a step_wise fashion until no highly correlated variables remained (Phillips et al�2006; Merow et al�2013; Barragan et al�2023).
#Text=In total, 11 predictors were used in the final Maxent model (Table�1).
#Text=All variables were sampled at a 30m resolution across the same geographic extent spanning the state of Michigan with a 1km coastal buffer (Fig�1).
#Text=Climatic variables, which were initially downloaded from�worldclim.org�at 30_second (1km2) resolutions, were re_sampled to a 30m resolution using the nearest neighbor technique.
#Text=ArcGIS (version 10.8.1) was used to create all spatial data layers and convert them into ASCII files for use in Maxent.
#Text=All statistical analysis took place in R (version 4.0.3).
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�A description of 11 environmental predictors that were identified as important to wild rice viability in the state of Michigan and used in the Maxent model.

#Text=Variable\rUnits\rSource\rDam presence\r0 or 1\rNational Inventory of Dams (2020)\rMuskrat presence\r0 or 1\rOndatra�Link, 1795 in GBIF Secretariat (2019)\rLand_use/land_cover\r19 categories\rDewitz (2019)\rPlant community\r24 categories\rBourgeau_Chavez et al (2015)\rHardiness zone\r degrees C\rUSDA Plant Hardiness Zone Map (2015)\rMay precipitation\rmm\rFick and Hijmans (2017)\rAnnual mean temperature\r degrees C\rFick and Hijmans (2017)\rAnnual temperature range\r degrees C\rFick and Hijmans (2017)\rAnnual precipitation\rmm\rFick and Hijmans (2017)\rPrecipitation seasonality\rCoefficient of variation\rFick and Hijmans (2017)\rPrecipitation of wettest quarter\rmm\rFick and Hijmans (2017)\r\rFigure 1\r\rResponse curves for six continuous predictor variables used in the Maxent model that show how each variable affects model predictions.
#Text=Logistical outputs closer to 1 indicate a high probability of occurrence.
#Text=The curves show the mean response of the five replicate Maxent runs (black) +/_1 SD (orange).
#Text=Model Configuration\rWe used the machine learning algorithm maximum entropy (Maxent, version 4.3.4) to generate our habitat suitability model.
#Text=Maxent compares environmental conditions at species occurrence sites to those at randomly generated background sites, which are treated as pseudo_absences.

#Text=It then creates a probability distribution based on differences in environmental conditions at occurrence and background sites to identify suitable habitats for a species (Phillips et al�2006; Elith & Leathwick�2009).
#Text=We input our occurrence data and environmental predictors into the Maxent algorithm as CSV and ASCII files, respectively, with predictors classified as continuous or categorical.
#Text=A regularization multiplier of 1.0 was used and all other model parameters were similarly kept at their default value (Phillips et al�2017).
#Text=The default number of background points of 10,000 was used for each iteration.

#Text=The model's accuracy was then evaluated using a fivefold cross_validation where 20% of the occurrence data was used as a testing set and 80% of the data was used as a training set across five model iterations (Fielding & Bell�1997; Guisan & Zimmermann�2000; Merow et al�2013).
#Text=On average, 120 occurrence points and 10,000 background points were used in each model iteration.

#Text=We averaged predictions from all five iterations to create a habitat suitability map using Maxent's logistic output, which assigns relative probabilities from 0 to 1 for the geographic extent of the study, with increasing values indicating increasing probability of occurrence.
#Text=AUC is the most commonly used metric to evaluate Maxent model performance (Phillips et al�2006; Elith et al�2011; Merow et al�2013).
#Text=The AUC value is calculated by comparing the true and false positivity rates for a model run to determine how well the model is able to correctly distinguish between presence and absence sites.

#Text=AUC values range from 0 to 1, with a value of 0.5 or lower indicating that a model's predictions are as good as random and a value of 1 indicating perfect model fit (Swets�1988; Phillips et al�2006).
#Text=Results.
#Text=Model Predictions.

#Text=The AUC of our model was 0.944 with a standard deviation of 0.019, indicating that the model was a statistically accurate predictor of wild rice occurrence based on the environmental predictors and occurrence data used.
#Text=Overall, land cover, plant communities, May precipitation, and hardiness zones had the highest relative contributions, with land cover contributing almost 40% to the model.

#Text=Other bioclimatic variables, including annual mean temperature, annual precipitation, precipitation of the wettest quarter, precipitation seasonality, annual temperature range, and dam presence, contributed less than 5% to model fit.
#Text=Muskrat's presence did not contribute to the model at all (Table�2).
#Text=Table 2.
#Text=�Relative percent contributions of the 11 environmental predictors used in the Maxent model.
#Text=Higher percent values indicate higher contribution to the model fit.

#Text=Variable\rPercent contribution\rLand cover\r39.6\rPlant community\r22.3\rMay precipitation\r18.6\rHardiness zone\r14.1\rAnnual mean temperature\r2.9\rAnnual precipitation\r0.9\rPrecipitation of wettest quarter\r0.8\rPrecipitation seasonality\r0.3\rDam presence\r0.2\rAnnual temperature range\r0.1\rMuskrat presence\r0\rEnvironmental Variable Response\rResponse curves were calculated for each environmental variable to show how variables affect model predictions.
#Text=According to response curves generated by the model, wild rice occurrence was most associated with wetland and open water habitats (Fig�3B).

#Text=Areas classified as barren land were shown to have moderately high associations with wild rice presence, whereas areas with residential and agricultural development, forests, and grasslands, were all found to have little association with wild rice occurrence (Fig�3B).
#Text=The absence of dams was similarly more likely to predict wild rice occurrence (Fig�2B).
#Text=Figure 2\r\rResponse plots for four binary and categorical variables used in the Maxent model that show how each variable affects model predictions.
#Text=Logistical outputs closer to 1 indicate a higher probability of occurrence.
#Text=Plots show the mean response over five replicate Maxent runs with error bars indicating +/_1 SD.

#Text=In terms of biotic interactions, higher probabilities of occurrence were associated with several aquatic plant communities including aquatic beds and wetlands with rooted and floating vascular plants, algal beds, and aquatic mosses.
#Text=In addition, wild rice habitat was strongly associated with plant communities dominated by�Typha�spp and�Phragmites australis�(Fig�3A).
#Text=Figure 3\r\rResponse plots for (A) plant community class and (B) land_use land_cover variables used in the Maxent model that show how each variable affects model predictions.
#Text=Logistical outputs closer to 1 indicate a higher probability of occurrence.
#Text=Plots show the mean response over five replicate Maxent runs with error bars indicating +/_1 SD.
#Text=Moreover, bioclimatic trends influenced occurrence predictions.
#Text=Wild rice presence tended to be predicted by lower precipitation levels (Fig�1C�&�1D), but higher seasonality or annual variation (Fig�1E).
#Text=Lower annual mean temperatures (Fig�1B) and higher minimum winter temperatures (Fig�2A) were further associated with wild rice occurrence.
#Text=Statewide Habitat Suitability\rOverall, many areas near lakes and streams across the state were identified as highly suitable for wild rice occurrence based on model predictions (Fig�4A).
#Text=Suitable habitats identified by the model ranged widely geographically, although high_probability areas were most concentrated in the western and southwestern parts of the state.

#Text=In particular, Winegar Moraine landforms in the Upper Peninsula and Elkhart Till Plains in the southwestern portions of the state were ecoregions with high probabilities of occurrence (Omernik & Griffith�2014).
#Text=Coastal areas showed some of the highest probabilities of occurrence as well, particularly near Lake St.
#Text=Clair and within drowned river mouth systems along Lake Michigan.
#Text=Figure 4\r\r(A) Predicted probability of wild rice occurrence, averaged across five model iterations.
#Text=Darker colors indicate higher relative probability of occurrence.
#Text=(B) An example of a cluster of lakes in Ironwood Chapter Township, MI where probability of wild rice occurrence differs within lakes.
#Text=National Wetlands Inventory boundaries are outlined in gray (USFWS,�2023).
#Text=In addition, many areas within the same lake, river, or wetland system were found to have different probabilities of occurrence (Fig�4B).
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Our model results confirm that wild rice can grow in a wide range of naturally occurring wetland habitats throughout Michigan.
#Text=Suitable sites identified by the model spanned the entire geographic extent of the state, indicating that the restoration of wild rice across its historic statewide range may be possible.
#Text=Indeed, many sites identified by the model are areas where dense wild rice beds have historically occurred, such as areas near Lake St.
#Text=Clair, Lake Erie, and Lake Michigan (Barton�2018).

#Text=However, suitable site locations may also be constrained by the availability of wetlands habitat today, with land cover identified as the most influential variable in predicting wild rice occurrence (Vennum�1988; Barton�2018).
#Text=Since European colonization, land conversion has reduced the extent of freshwater wetlands in the conterminous 48 states, including Michigan, by half (Dahl�1990; Brinson & Malvarez�2002).
#Text=In our study, many historic sites that no longer have viable wetlands were found to be unsuitable for wild rice.
#Text=In addition, anthropogenic disturbances may restrict suitable wetland habitat.

#Text=The model predicted low probabilities of occurrence in areas with residential and agricultural development, which have been noted to limit wild rice growth in other studies as well (Pillsbury & McGuire�2009; Barton�2018).
#Text=Model results similarly suggest that the absence of dams is preferable for wild rice viability (Vennum�1988; Rickman et al�2017).
#Text=As such, although wild rice restoration continues to be feasible at a statewide scale, localized changes in land cover may influence viability and should be considered.

#Text=It should also be noted that while our model predicted a moderately high probability of occurrence on barren land, this may be attributed to discrepancies in land classification rather than species biology.

#Text=For instance, areas classified as barren land may still contain smaller wetlands, ditches, and so forth, which are not captured in the land cover dataset but may be viable habitats for wild rice (Hollister et al�2004).
#Text=These areas have been noted to contain wetlands plants in other datasets, such as the plant community dataset used (Bourgeau_Chavez et al�2015).

#Text=Establishing a more thorough understanding of wetland cover in the state as well as ground_truthing these maps may give better insight into the availability of suitable habitat for restoration as it pertains to land cover.
#Text=In areas where undisturbed wetlands are present, vegetative cover may further influence viability and should be considered in restoration efforts.

#Text=Our model found that wild rice occurrence was most associated with plant communities typically found in wetland and open_water ecosystems including rooted and floating vascular plants, algal beds, and aquatic mosses (Bourgeau_Chavez et al�2015).
#Text=Many of these plant communities have been associated with wild rice growth in previous studies (Engel & Nichols�1994; Pillsbury & McGuire�2009; Yost & Blinnikov�2011).

#Text=In addition, areas dominated by�Typha�spp and�Phragmites australis�were associated with wild rice presence by the model, although given the resolution of our data, these are more likely due to the widespread occurrence of these species in wetland habitats rather than facilitative species interactions.
#Text=Moreover, no distinction was made in our analysis between native and non_native taxa of�Typha�spp or�P. australis.

#Text=Non_native�Typha�spp and�P. australis�are widespread invasive emergent plant species in the Great Lakes region (Zedler & Kercher�2004; Carson et al�2018) and achieve wetland plant community dominance through multi_year litter accumulation and competitive exclusion (Holdredge & Bertness�2011; Larkin et al�2012).

#Text=Positive associations between wild rice beds and these species (both native and non_native) have been documented, but further analysis of potential competitive impacts on wild rice is necessary (Engel & Nichols�1994; Yost & Blinnikov�2011; Bonello & Judd�2020).

#Text=Similarly, a wide range of other macrophytes and aquatic plants identified by previous studies as influential to wild rice growth were not included in this model due to limitations in publicly available, statewide datasets (Engel & Nichols�1994; Bonnette�1999; Pillsbury & McGuire�2009).

#Text=Given that plant community types contributed largely to our model predictions, further analysis of specific plant species interactions, including invasive macrophytes, may be particularly beneficial in guiding restoration efforts.
#Text=In addition to localized wetland conditions, broader climatic trends were also significant predictors of wild rice occurrence and may be particularly influential in the face of climate change.
#Text=In particular, May precipitation contributed more to model predictions than any other climatic variable.
#Text=These findings align with our biological understanding of the species; in Michigan, wild rice typically germinates in April�May and enters the floating leaf stage soon after (Barton�2018).

#Text=Monthly precipitation during germination and floating leaf stages are more influential than annual precipitation trends as wild rice is typically still developing root and shoot systems during these critical stages and may be especially sensitive to water level changes spurred by precipitation (Whigham & Simpson�1977; Rickman et al�2017; Barton�2018).

#Text=Extreme precipitation has also been found to be a deterrent to wild rice growth at other life stages (Thomas & Stewart�1969; Stevenson & Lee�1987) and model findings reflect this association, as lower annual precipitation, particularly during the wettest quarter of the year, is more conducive to wild rice occurrence.

#Text=As extreme precipitation events are predicted to increase in Michigan, impacting hydrologic water flow during the spring and summer months (Cherkauer & Sinha�2010; Kim et al�2016) these findings suggest that suitable wild rice habitats may also be affected.
#Text=In addition, higher precipitation seasonality was associated with a greater probability of occurrence.

#Text=Previous studies have similarly noted that fluctuations in precipitation may be beneficial for wild rice by providing windows of opportunity for dormant seeds to emerge during times when the presence of competing macrophytes might be diminished (Rickman et al�2017; Barton�2018).
#Text=As such, while extreme precipitation events may serve as a detriment, seasonal fluctuations in precipitation may be conducive to wild rice viability.
#Text=Similarly, extreme temperatures may play a critical role in the success of future restoration, particularly in the face of climate change.

#Text=Wild rice occurrence was generally predicted in areas with lower average annual temperatures, confirming previous findings that lower temperatures increase wild rice germination and growth rates, particularly in the winter when seeds require minimum temperatures for overwintering (Myrbo et al�2017; Rickman et al�2017).

#Text=A study by Kovach and Bradford (1992) similarly found that wild rice germination may require a relatively narrow range of winter temperatures spanning from 10 to 3 degrees C, and temperatures that fall outside of this range may significantly decrease viability.
#Text=The sensitivity of wild rice to lower temperature ranges may be particularly concerning in the face of climate change.
#Text=Indeed, the southern range of wild rice has already been noted to be shifting northward in certain states in response to warming temperatures (Porter�2019).

#Text=Likewise, extremely high temperatures may limit the growth and viability of mature plants due to higher levels of stress, invasive species pressure, and water level fluctuations (Rickman et al�2017; Porter�2019).
#Text=Further climate modeling may be a useful tool in understanding how climatic trends in precipitation and temperature will shift wild rice distributions and suitable habitats for restoration.

#Text=Overall, highly suitable locations for wild rice occurrence were more concentrated in the western parts of Michigan that are closer to the Wisconsin border and Minnesota�states where rice beds are much more prevalent (Drewes & Silbernagel�2012; Rickman et al�2017; Porter�2019).

#Text=Although different histories of wild rice cultivation and anthropogenic disturbance are likely key drivers behind these differences (Drewes & Silbernagel�2012; Barton�2018; Porter�2019), differences in environmental conditions in the western parts of the state, such as the distribution of lake effect microclimates may also play a contributing role and may be a useful consideration in restoration efforts.
#Text=Model Limitations.
#Text=Limitations in publicly available, statewide data related to wild rice and its habitat posed key challenges throughout the study.
#Text=Ten of the eleven variables considered as part of our model were associated with wild rice presence and may be key drivers of wild rice occurrence in the state of Michigan.
#Text=However, we were unable to include numerous variables that had insufficient publicly available statewide data, although these variables may play a key role in wild rice viability.

#Text=Water depth (Thomas & Stewart�1969; Vennum�1988; Myrbo et al�2017) and water chemistry (Pillsbury & McGuire�2009; Sims et al�2012; Fort et al�2014) were not included in the model due to data limitations even though they have been noted as key drivers of wild rice occurrence in previous studies and by the MWRI monitoring and restoration subcommittee.

#Text=While our model found some areas within the center of large lakes as having higher probabilities of occurrence, deep water in these areas indicate that they would likely be unsuitable in reality if water depth was accounted for.
#Text=Although muskrat distribution was included as a model variable, it had zero contribution to the model's final predictions.

#Text=Data limitations may have reduced the predictive power of this variable as it was derived from limited observation data, and estimates of population abundance and density were not taken into account.

#Text=Previous studies have found that muskrat populations can disturb wild rice seeding and growth due to herbivory and, as such, the use of more expanded datasets may lead to more accurate conclusions on the effects of muskrat presence (Takos�1947; Rogosin�1954; Barton�2018).
#Text=Furthermore, the species occurrence data that was used in this model did not distinguish between�Zizania palustris�and�Zizania aquatica�due to limitations in available statewide data.

#Text=Although both species have historically co_occurred widely throughout the state, some habitat preferences have been noted between the two, with�Z. palustris�being more commonly found in inland lakes, rivers, and marshes in the northern part of the state and�Z. aquatica�being more frequently found in slow_moving rivers in the south (Barton�2018).

#Text=As wild rice restoration efforts increase, the availability of statewide datasets that make clearer distinctions between�Z. palustris�and�Z. aquatica�may be important in determining suitable restoration sites for each species, respectively, particularly as sufficient genetic diversity may be an influential factor in restoration success (Diller et al�2018; Porter�2019).

#Text=Guiding Future Restoration Efforts\rSDMs such as the Maxent model created in this study may be effective tools in helping guide restoration efforts for wild rice on a regional or statewide scale.

#Text=Large_scale species distribution or habitat mapping tools have not been used yet, to the best of our knowledge, for identifying wild rice restoration sites in the Great Lakes region or nationally, despite their widespread use in guiding restorations of threatened plant species generally (Gaston & Garcia_Vinas�2013; Questad et al�2014; Zellmer et al�2019).

#Text=As wild rice remains a culturally and economically important plant that can face significant barriers to restoration, including limitations in seed supply, drastic changes to historical habitat, and ongoing environmental threats (Porter�2019), being able to more effectively identify and evaluate restoration sites may be critical for restoration efforts.
#Text=While our model addresses environmental factors that might influence habitat for wild rice, it is important to note that not all ecologically viable habitats may be suited for restoration.

#Text=Restoration on public, private, and tribal lands all pose different management implications that need to be taken into account when planning wild rice restorations at large scales (Drewes & Silbernagel�2012).
#Text=A more thorough understanding of how land ownership and land_use practices can influence the availability of suitable areas may be important.

#Text=In addition, geographic isolation of wild rice populations due to habitat loss or environmental preferences can also pose challenges in terms of recruitment and maintaining genetic diversity and may be an important consideration for choosing restoration sites (Porter�2019).

#Text=Through further field verification and the inclusion of more key predictors, the habitat suitability map created by this study may serve as an effective guide for identifying sites for wild rice seeding and restoration in Michigan and beyond.
#Text=As climate change and anthropogenic disturbance intensify in the coming decades, the wetland habitats in which wild rice occurs will likely continue to be threatened.

#Text=Understanding the ways in which these changes impact the viability of wild rice and the natural and human communities that depend on them may consequently be critical for our ecological, cultural, and economic health.
